Gateway Classic Cars of San Antonio/Austin is proud to present this head-turning 1970 Plymouth Road Runner. With a full rotisserie restoration, this Road Runner is ready to win trophies and drop jaws. This timeless muscle car boasts a glossy Hemi Orange exterior that is sure to stand out on the road. The engine bay is finished just as nicely as the rest of the car, so you'll proudly show off this pristine space. Everyone wants a Mopar with a Hemi, but this one is a cut-above. Beneath its aggressive stance lies a fuel injected 500 CID V8 monster of an engine, seamlessly paired with a Tremec TKO 5-speed manual transmission with the obligatory Pistol Grip Hurst shifter! The motor has been worked up with a Comp Cams Hydraulic roller cam, Diamond Racing pistons, Harland Sharp roller rocker, Edelbrock aluminum heads, aluminum radiator, and a March Performance pulley set pumping out an impressive 498HP and an Earth spinning 561LBFT or torque. All this power gets sent to the massive Mickey Thompson wheels out back via a shorted Dana 60 rear differential with 4:30 gears and Moser axles. The interior is a nice blend of modern and original with the redone factory bucket seats, a modern Alpine AM/FM/CD/AUX radio with Infinity speakers. The back seat has been upholstered to match the front bucket seats and matching door panels have been painted in high gloss black. Cold A/C helps keep that interior comfortable as well. The Road Runner doesn't just excel in performance; it also promises a smooth and effortless ride with its Hydro boost power steering and Wilwood power disc brakes in all 4 corners, redone K-member, custom traction bars, making it a pleasure to drive whether you're cruising down the highway or the drag strip. This 1970 Plymouth Road Runner is a high-end build that is sure to be the star of any collection! First Name Please provide a first name. Last Name Please provide a last name. Gateway Classic Cars of Philadelphia is proud to present this beautifully restored 1965 Ford Mustang GT350 Tribute. Completed by the renowned Cobra Automotive Inc., this build is a comprehensive ground-up restoration, crafted to mirror the iconic Shelby GT350 in both appearance and spirit. Finished in a striking navy metallic blue with classic white racing stripes, this tribute pays homage to the original with careful attention to every detail-from GT350 badging to custom exterior accents that echo the look and feel of the real thing. Underneath its show-quality exterior lies a fully re-engineered drivetrain and chassis, where every component has been thoughtfully replaced or rebuilt. From the engine bay to the undercarriage, new brake lines, cables, wiring, and hardware have been installed to ensure both function and reliability. Powering this Mustang is a professionally built 331 cubic inch stroker V8 engine, featuring a 10.2:1 compression ratio and a full complement of Edelbrock valvetrain components. The build includes Edelbrock aluminum heads, a performance camshaft, forged pistons, and an Edelbrock intake manifold-all backed by a comprehensive set of receipts and documentation outlining the specifications and craftsmanship behind the engine. The power is managed through a 5-speed manual transmission, paired with a Centerforce dual-friction clutch for smooth and responsive gear changes. A steel driveshaft delivers torque to a durable 9-inch rear end, rounding out a drivetrain built for both performance and enjoyment. Whether you're looking to take this car to the shows or simply enjoy the feel of a well-built tribute to one of Ford's most legendary performance machines, this GT350 replica represents a high level of build quality and attention to detail. Gateway Classic Cars St. Louis is proud digitally present this 1969 Chevrolet Camaro. This car is built with a laundry list of performance parts. Starting with TCI front & rear subframes and a torque arm rear suspension with Viking adjustable coil-overs, the Flex-Fuel tuned, supercharged LSA crate motor running a Lingenfelter GT15 cam and 2.5" pulley puts the power down through a Tremec TR6060. A custom stainless 3" exhaust flows through Black Widow mufflers and it all sounds incredible! A Wilwood big brake setup with drilled & slotted rotors clamped by piston calipers up front and back provide the stopping force while a rack & pinion setup and a meaty set of Toyo R888R's wrapped around staggered Rushforth Night Train wheels, tucked into Detroit Speed mini-tubs, gives a muscular footprint. This unique and completely custom Camaro build has a full TMI interior, beautifully finished in striking black, a suite of Autometer gauges and Vintage Air heat & A/C, power windows and a bluetooth Sony head unit rounding out the amenities. Gateway Classic Cars of Las Vegas is excited to digitally present this truly iconic piece of automotive history: the 1961 Volkswagen Samba Bus 23 Window. This classic vehicle is a testament to the timeless design and engineering prowess of Volkswagen during the early 1960s. The exterior of this Samba Bus is adorned in a striking pink color, offering a vibrant and unique aesthetic that is sure to turn heads wherever it goes. The 23 windows, including the distinctive skylight windows, provide an unparalleled panoramic view and a sense of openness that is synonymous with the Samba Bus experience. Step inside, and you'll be greeted by a crafted interior featuring luxurious gray leather seating. The choice of leather not only adds a touch of elegance but also ensures comfort for both driver and passengers. The spacious cabin is designed to accommodate your adventures, whether you're cruising along the coast or embarking on a cross-country journey. The interior layout is both functional and stylish, reflecting the thoughtful design that Volkswagen is renowned for. Under the hood, this Samba Bus is equipped with a Flat 4 engine, a hallmark of Volkswagen's engineering during this era. Paired with a manual transmission, this powertrain offers an engaging driving experience that allows you to fully appreciate the nuances of this classic vehicle. The combination of the Flat 4 engine and manual transmission ensures a connection to the road that is both authentic and exhilarating. Details as stated by the seller: Color is L53 Sealing Wax Red, Roof, L472 Beige Grey and Upholstery Silver Beige. Documentation from the VW AutoMuseum is Wolfsburg states the motor is the original one from the new manufacturing as well as detailing the build and shipping to the US in 1961 where it was delivered to Texas and sold. Model 241, VW Microbus De Luxe "Samba" was produced 22 June 1961 before being shipped on 30 June 1961 to USA Tourists. Multiple Texas registration papers from the 1960s accompany the sale. This 1961 Volkswagen Samba Bus 23 Window is more than just a vehicle; it is a symbol of a bygone era, a celebration of design, and a testament to the enduring appeal of Volkswagen's craftsmanship. Whether you're a collector, an enthusiast, or someone who appreciates the charm of vintage automobiles, this Samba Bus offers an opportunity to own a piece of history that continues to inspire and captivate. Gateway Classic Cars Houston Showroom is proud to present this 1965 Chevrolet Impala SS restomod. This fully re-engineered 1965 Impala SS blends classic style with modern performance. At the heart is a fresh CHEVY BBC 496ci (505hp) Stage 6.0 engine built on a Dart Big M block - an aftermarket block engineered for maximum durability and strength. Dart's Big M blocks feature precision machining, superior strength, and priority main oiling to ensure reliability and power. Inside the block, we've installed Wiseco forged pistons. Unlike cast pistons, Wiseco's high-strength forged aluminum pistons are lighter and stronger, allowing higher compression and revving without failure. In practice this means the Impala's engine can handle serious horsepower and abuse while remaining rock-solid. The fuel system is modernized with an Edelbrock Pro-Flo electronic fuel injection kit, replacing the old carburetor. EFI ensures each cylinder gets the precise fuel metering it needs under all conditions, delivering instant throttle response and smoother power delivery. It provides crisp, solid shifts and a reliable connection between the big-block's power and the rear wheels. Complementing this is a Ram precision-machined billet steel flywheel. The heavy-duty Ram flywheel adds useful inertia for smooth launch and low-speed drivability. Paired with a high-performance twin-disc clutch kit from McLeod Racing, this drivetrain launches the Impala with confidence. The McLeod twin-clutch design doubles the friction surface area, allowing enormous grip without the extra weight of a single huge clutch. As Motor Trend notes, a McLeod twin-disc clutch delivers "mega grip without the extra weight" - it's about 10 pounds lighter than stock, yet it grips more firmly and requires less pedal effort. In short, this engine-and-transmission package lets you "get on it" with a light, positive clutch feel while the forged internals and billet components handle the abuse. The chassis of this Impala has been completely reworked for modern handling. Up front and out back the suspension uses fully adjustable coil-over shock-and-spring assemblies. Unlike the old leaf springs and shocks, coil overs allow precise control of ride height and damping, so the car's body is flat and planted in corners. Coil-over systems are prized in performance builds because they are "fully tunable" for both spring preload and shock valving, delivering "better geometry" and a firmer, more controlled ride than stock setups. With the adjustable springs, you can lower the car for a lower center of gravity and stiffen it for aggressive street driving, yet still retain comfort on the highway. The suspension arms themselves have been upgraded to heavy-duty tubular control arms. These modern arms are made from high-strength steel tubing, making them lighter and stronger than the original stamped-steel A-arms. The tubular design also corrects the outdated geometry of the stock setup, allowing more negative camber and optimal caster angles. In fact, QA1 - a leading suspension manufacturer - explains that tubular control arms reduce unsprung weight and allow modern alignment settings (like extra negative camber gain) that vastly improve handling. In practice this means better turn-in grip and stability under load. Inside, the Impala balances classic character with driver comfort. The bucket seats and door panels are trimmed in durable black cloth, accented by supple black leather in key areas for a touch of luxury. This combination was chosen for both its classic muscle-car appearance and its comfort. Modern conveniences abound: factory-style air conditioning keeps the cabin cool in summer, while a retro-styled AM/FM radio and premium sound system lets you enjoy music in cruise mode. Power steering, power brakes, and power door locks make everyday driving easy and comfortable. Even the tilt-adjustable steering wheel lets drivers of any size find the ideal position. Custom alloy wheels with modern wide radial tires add a distinctive look and grip, and a comfortable front bench and rear seat ensure the Impala is just as functional as it is powerful. In short, the interior feels like a well-equipped classic: vintage charm with all the modern usability features you expect in a high-end restomod. The end result is an Impala SS that drives like a modern performance sedan but sounds and feels like old-school muscle. Throttle input is met with instant response from the EFI'd 505ci V8, and the exhaust bellow combines classic big-block roar with seamless idle and midrange due to modern tuning. The hydraulic McLeod twin-disc clutch, paired with the balanced Ram flywheel, allows the engine to rev freely off the stop but also gives smooth engagement when launching - you can feel the full torque of the motor without any hesitation or chattering. Shifts through the robust Tremec five-speed are positive and precise, thanks to a short-throw shifter and modern linkage. What truly sets this Impala apart is how the upgraded engine and suspension work together. The stiffened chassis and coil-overs mean that when you floor it or dive into a corner, the body remains flat and predictable. The tires bite the pavement, and the steering is sharp and direct - far removed from the vague feel of the original. Combined with those massive Wilwood brakes, the car begs to be driven hard. Experienced drivers will appreciate that this classic no longer softly wallows through curves; instead it rewards aggressive inputs with true muscle-car thrills. Even at highway speeds, the car is stable and controlled, not only thanks to the suspension but also the 50-year newer tires and modern alignment. In summary, this 1965 Impala SS resto-mod blends raw power with refinement. Each upgrade was chosen to make the car as drivable and reliable as possible. The result is a true high-performance classic: one that you can hop in for a leisurely Sunday cruise or take on a winding back road and wring out its legs. It evokes the visceral excitement of vintage muscle - the rumble, the quick throttle response - but it behaves like a modern sports car. It's a thrilling, instant classic that delivers modern handling, braking, and comfort without losing any of that legendary 1960s attitude. With powerful polished V8 under the hood, precise suspension, and thoughtful amenities inside, this Impala SS is ready to excite any enthusiast who loves a blend of nostalgia and capability. Gateway Classic Cars Houston Showroom is proud to present this 1969 Chevrolet Chevelle 396SS. The 1969 Chevrolet Chevelle SS396 stands as a pinnacle of the classic American muscle car era. Few cars stood out from the rest like the 1969 L78 SS396 Chevelle, and enthusiasts regard the Chevelle as one of the most iconic muscle cars ever. For 1969 the Chevelle's long-hood, short-deck styling (introduced in 1968) continued, and Chevrolet reintroduced the highest-output 396 cubic-inch engine in its lineup. The SS396 hardtop (and convertible) could be ordered with the legendary L78 option - a 375-horsepower version of the Turbo-Jet 396 - which cemented the Chevelle's reputation for bold styling paired with truly high-end performance. The L78 option was famously elusive and rare. It was never listed in the standard sales brochures, requiring a special dealer order (RPO L78). he L78 option was expensive for its day ($252.80 in 1969) and delivered an uncompromising 375 horsepower (with 415lb-ft torque at 3, 600rpm)Only 9, 486 Chevelles were built from the factory with the L78 in 1969. Today the L78 396 is highly prized by collectors for its rarity and historical significance - a verified L78 engine code (as recorded on the L78 registry) is a potent mark of authenticity and investment value. Mechanically, the L78 396 was a thoroughly race-ready big-block. It was the only factory SS396 engine with four-bolt main bearing caps, and it used a nitrided forged-steel crankshaft for extreme durability. Chevrolet equipped the L78 with solid lifters, 11.5:1 compression pistons, and aggressive cam profiles. The iron cylinder heads were the high-performance "square-port" design with massive 2.19-inch intake valves. Breathing was handled by a cast-aluminum high-rise intake manifold (often called a Winters "snowflake" manifold) feeding a 4150-series Holley vacuum-secondary four-barrel carburetor rated at 780cfm. In stock form this combination yielded the factory 375hp at 5, 600rpm and 415lb-ft at 3, 600rpm.In short, the L78's forged internals, robust valvetrain, and generous airflow made it one of Chevrolet's most potent production engines of the era. This specific Chevelle SS396 is finished in its original Orange exterior paint over a carefully redone black interior. The L78 engine has been rebuilt by Competition Auto Machine (Spring, Texas) to factory specifications, with a modern roller cam installed for reliability while preserving the correct power curve. The drivetrain uses the correct Muncie M20 wide-ratio four-speed manual transmission and a heavy-duty 12-bolt rear end. Notably, the rear end now wears 3.73:1 gears (upgraded from the original 4.11:1) for a more usable cruising ratio. Restoration work was scrupulous: the bare frame was media-blasted and powder-coated, and all suspension and steering components were rebuilt to original F41 SS396 specification. The car is equipped with period-correct amenities (and some sympathetic upgrades): Vintage Air air conditioning (styled like factory A/C), an AM/FM radio, power steering and original-style power-assisted front disc brakes (the rear discs also updated for safety), plus modern radial tires and lap seatbelts. Overall, the fit and finish reflect a high-quality restoration that balances authenticity with drivability and comfort. Owning this 1969 Chevrolet Chevelle SS396 L78 is far more than acquiring a restored classic; it is securing a piece of muscle car history that represents the peak of Chevrolet's engineering in the golden era. With its verified L78 registration, restoration, and painstakingly accurate mechanical rebuild, this Chevelle stands among the most desirable examples available today. The combination of rarity, performance pedigree, and thorough restoration ensures that it is not only a car to be enjoyed on the road but also one that will continue to appreciate in value as demand for authentic investment-grade muscle cars grows. For the discerning collector, this Chevelle is the kind of opportunity that does not come around often-equal parts showpiece, performer, and blue-chip investment. Gateway Classic Cars of Louisville is proud to present this stunning 1970 Plymouth Road Runner 440 Six Pack! The 1970 Road Runner stands as one of the most recognized and respected muscle cars of its time-bold, brash, and built to perform. This example, a factory V-Code 440 Six Pack, 4-speed car (VIN: RM23V0E119421), captures everything enthusiasts love about classic Mopar muscle while reflecting the care and attention of thoughtful ownership. Built in November 1969 at the Los Angeles Assembly Plant and reportedly sold new through Friendly Chrysler Plymouth Inc. of Los Angeles, California, this Road Runner is accompanied by documentation including its window sticker and fender tag, supporting its identity as a V-Code 440 Six Pack 4-speed car. Undergoing a rotisserie restoration in 2004, this Road Runner remains striking in every detail. The exterior is finished in brilliant Lemon Twist Yellow (Y1), accented by a black vinyl top (V1X), black performance hood paint (V21), and transverse black stripes (V8X). This color combination is absolutely eye-catching and commands attention wherever it goes. Pull into a show, and the deep rumble of that 440 Six Pack V8 paired with the vivid Lemon Twist paint is sure to turn heads. Inside, the black vinyl bucket seats (P6XA) and Rallye gauge cluster create an environment designed for the driver. Grab the Hurst pistol-grip shifter, and you'll immediately feel that unmistakable Mopar connection between man and machine. Under the hood, the 440 cubic inch Six Pack V8 breathes through triple two-barrel Holley carburetors and is paired with the legendary A833 4-speed manual transmission. Flip the switch for the Air Grabber hood, and the scoop rises to pull in fresh air-an experience that never gets old. Performance appears to be enhanced by A33 Track Pak equipment, including a 9-inch Dana rear axle with 3.54 gears, heavy-duty suspension, and upgraded cooling and braking systems. Together, they deliver the kind of raw, mechanical thrill that defined the golden age of muscle cars. The odometer shows 73, 677 miles, indicating years of careful use and preservation since the restoration. From the sound of the Six Pack's idle to the feel of that pistol-grip shifter, this Road Runner isn't just a car-it's an experience. The Lemon Twist finish pops in the sunlight, the exhaust note commands attention, and every drive feels like a trip back to 1970. This is the kind of car that turns every outing into an event. Features include: Air Grabber hood, Rallye Road Wheels, AM radio with 8-track stereo, dual exhaust, black vinyl top, transverse stripe package, and raised white-letter tires. This 1970 Plymouth Road Runner 440 Six Pack is offered by our Louisville Showroom and can be viewed in greater detail including 100+ HD pictures and an HD video at www.GatewayClassicCars.com . For additional information, please call our knowledgeable staff or email us at Louisville@ GatewayClassicCars.com - Our Louisville Showroom is located at 13576 Blue Lick Rd. Ste A, Memphis, IN 47143. Gateway Classic Cars of St. Louis is proud to digitally present this fully restored 1971 Plymouth Cuda, finished in striking TorRed Orange with a bold orange interior. Few cars define the golden age of Mopar muscle like the '71 Cuda, and this example represents one of the most desirable combinations of color, performance, and presence. For 1971, Plymouth gave the Cuda its only major styling update of the E-body generation, including quad headlights, new grille design, fender gills, and tail panel revisions that emphasized aggression and performance. These cues, along with bold high-impact paint colors like TorRed, cemented the Cuda as one of the most iconic muscle cars of its time. Today, the 1971 model year is celebrated as one of the pinnacles of Mopar history - a year when bold design and big performance met just before emissions standards and insurance rates began to close the chapter on the muscle car era. This example brings that heritage to life with a 383 cubic inch V8 engine tucked under the functional shaker hood, delivering classic Mopar rumble and muscle. It's paired with the highly desirable A833 4-speed manual transmission, giving you the visceral, hands-on experience enthusiasts crave. Inside, the orange leather interior matches the exterior, creating a bold, cohesive presentation that stands out just as much today as it did when it rolled off the line. Every inch of this car has been restored with attention to detail, ensuring both authenticity and show-stopping appeal. Highlights include: 383 V8 engine with shaker hood A833 4-speed manual transmission TorRed Orange exterior with matching orange interior Full restoration Legendary 1971 model year styling updates This 1971 Plymouth Cuda isn't just a muscle car - it's a cultural icon, representing the peak of Plymouth's performance lineup and one of the most collectible Mopars of all time. Gateway Classic Cars of Orlando is excited to present this 1968 Plymouth Barracuda, a classic example of one of America's most famous, iconic, and recognizable racecars, that turns heads wherever it goes. Built to be driven on the street, you can experience the rare performance of a professionally built race hemi as well as cruise to your favorite car show or drive-in. First impressions are important and the bright silver paint on this gorgeous Barracuda leaves you almost speechless. The multiple layers of "Billet Silver" beautifully applied by Rick Perry of Rick Perry's Custom Paints shimmers from all angles in the sun or shade. Equally impressive is the interior. The vibrant blue interior with crushed pile carpet and tweed accents creates a striking contrast to the dazzling Billet Silver paint. The build itself began after an exhaustive search by a very demanding owner for a well preserved desert body. The search resulted in finding a car with the above qualifications. The car was then shipped to John Wallauer Race Cars in St Cloud Florida for complete disassembly and fabrication. John Wallauer is renowned for his many high-quality and award winning builds. The result was even more accolades from show judges who knew what they were looking at. This gleaming 1968 Cuda has won numerous first place awards throughout the Southeastern states, including First in Class at the prestigious Mopars At Big Daddy's Annual Car Show. Additionally, it was also a feature car in Mopar Muscle Magazine. Some owner stated features include: -tuned by Randy Blanchard -all factory body panels -Reilly Motorsports coil-over front suspension -Flaming River rack and pinion steering -BeCool Polished Billet Aluminum Radiator with dual Spal fans -MSD electronic ignition system -Edelbrock hemi aluminum heads -Cam Motion hydraulic roller #X2291-2341-10 -correct Holly dual 770 carbs -A&A aluminum cross ram intake -JW Performance 727 transmission -B & M shifter with reverse manual valve body -Gear Vendor Overdrive -Narrowed Dana 60 w/ 323 gears -JW Performance 2800 stall converter -Customized aluminum fuel tank -Aeromotive Phantom electric fuel system -Narrowed rear housing with widened rear rims -Mini tubbed ...and much more. In conclusion, this 1968 Plymouth Barracuda is a rare find, considering the "no expense spared" level of this build. Don't miss out on this opportunity to experience what famous Mopar race car drivers like Ronnie Sox experienced, but also cruise to a car show. First Name Please provide a first name. Gateway Classic Cars of San Antonio/Austin is privileged to be able to offer this very rare & highly collectible 1940 Packard 110 wood-bodied station wagon. The first Packard station wagon appeared in the fledgling "Six" model line in 1939 and the company sold 500 examples of the station wagon that first year. That popularity of the "Woody" station wagon prompted them to enlist the services of the long-established Hercules Body Company of Evansville, Indiana, for its 1940 wagons in both the 110 and 120 lineups. (This example being Body# 298). The Hercules Company was a very established company by this point in history; their initial trade having been as carriage builders just after the turn of the century. The 1940 wood-bodied Packard's were made of ash frames with birch panels. (At an additional cost, Mahogany panels could be ordered). For 1940, Packard supplied 358 Hercules bodies for the combined 110 and 120 model lines. The "110" models, which had a 122-inch wheelbase with a six-cylinder engine, while the "120" models had a 127-inch wheelbase and an eight-cylinder engine. The body designs were identical with the extra length on the One-Twenty being utilized by the larger engine and the firewall. This 1940 Packard 110 example rests on a 122-inch wheelbase chassis (Chassis #13832178) and is powered by a 245 cubic-inch flathead six-cylinder engine (Engine# C-19230B). This car was delivered in May of 1940 by the Boston Packard dealer and by the mid-1970s had been moved into the care of a California resident, where it was treated to a complete makeover by that owner. Upon completion, it was placed in a specially built alcove in the owner's living room! It appeared on the cover of Packard's International magazine in 1989, which was one of its very few public showings, and then later passed to another collector who had it kept in a climate-controlled storage area and treated to another extensive restoration to original specifications by Custom Auto Service in 2006-2007 and is also an esteemed Packard International Circle of Champions vehicle. Less than a dozen Packard 110 Station Wagons are known to be in existence & only one or two in the completely collectible condition of this car. In 2007 it was brought to the Gooding & Company auction held in Pebble Beach, Ca. where it was estimated to sell for $200, 000 - $260, 000. While those estimates were not achieved, the lot was still sold in 2007 for a whopping $181, 500! This is a very rare opportunity to acquire an investment grade, museum quality 1940 Packard 110 Woody Wagon that only comes along every couple decades, so don't miss out on this chance to join the ultra-exclusive collector club. Gateway Classic Cars Houston Showroom is excited to offer this very custom 1966 Chevrolet NOVA SS hardtop for sale. The striking maroon exterior is paired beautifully with a sophisticated tan interior to create a timeless and elegant aesthetic. This iconic model is powered by a potent Chevrolet Small Block V8 engine, which is backed by a 6-speed manual transmission. The SBC is reportedly a 391 CID stroker, based off a GM ZZ383, but we cannot verify the displacement. The dyno sheets indicate it's pushing 479HP/426 Lb-Ft torque at 5900 RPM. Clearly, the Brodix aluminum heads, Edelbrock aluminum intake, Holley 4BBL, Dougs Headers, and custom dual exhaust system help this mighty mouse breathe! This combo delivers the power and performance enthusiasts crave. Further custom and performance touches include a custom aluminum radiator with twin electric fans, a CVF Black Diamond front of engine kit with serpentine accessory drive, adjustable coilover shocks at all 4 corners (Aldans up front, and QA1 out back), a McLeod hydraulic clutch and Lakewood scattershield. Out back, the Ford 9-inch rear end features an adjustable multilink setup, with Strange Engineering axles and Moser ring and pinion gears (ratio unknown). Inside, the 1966 NOVA SS offers exceptional comfort and modern conveniences. A Dakota Digital retro gauge cluster provides a vintage look with modern accuracy for reporting key systems' status. The custom diamond-stitch leather seating (with power driver's seat) ensures a plush and adjustable driving experience (plus, the cabin has that very pleasing aroma that high-grade hides are known for). Adding to the driving pleasure is a Vintage Air HVAC system, keeping the cabin cool and comfortable on every journey. The chromed Flaming River tilt steering column with a billet wheel provides both style and ergonomic control, while the power steering with Flaming River rack ensures precise maneuverability. Entertainment is at the forefront with a RetroSound AM/FM/XM radio equipped with Bluetooth connectivity, allowing you to enjoy your favorite tunes and stay connected on the go. The power windows offer convenience and ease, seamlessly integrating modern amenities into this classic vehicle. Both front and rear occupants will appreciate the full-length center console, with its polished redwood insert and custom cupholders for all. Safety and performance have been enhanced with nitrogen-pressurized power disc brakes featuring adjustable front/rear bias, and along with Wilwood calipers and drilled/slotted rotors, offer superior stopping power. The addition of BF Goodrich Radial T/A tires and Cragar wheels not only boosts the vehicle's aesthetic appeal but also ensures a smooth and reliable ride. This 1966 Chevrolet NOVA SS strikes a great balance between vintage charm and modern upgrades, making it an extraordinary choice for any classic car aficionado. Gateway Classic Cars of Nashville is proud to present this 1989 Rolls-Royce Niko Michael 4 door conversion Corniche II. You heard that right a 4 door conversion. Believed to be a one of two. The only 4 door Corniche II in existence. The MSRP on this elegant piece of British engineering was over $200k new. The conversion was another $150k. The process to convert the vehicle from a 2 door to a 4 door was over 5000 man hours. Some of you in the know will recall Presley "Pres" Blake as the original owner of the vehicle. After leaving his collection it has been with the same family since around 2000. Before the vehicle came into our showroom it had over $10k in service work. The clean Carfax also show extensive service records from previous years. We have documentation on all of the work done in the past year. It has a newer Pioneer Bluetooth radio with upgraded speakers. Aside from that this vehicle is all stock. Be warned if you are looking for a plane jane Rolls Royce this isn't the one for you. We have plenty of non custom examples on our website. But if you are the kind of person that likes to have something no one else has. Then THIS is the Rolls Royce for you! Gateway Classic Cars of Kansas City is proud to present a blend of classic style and modern performance with this stunning 1956 Ford Ranch Wagon Pro-Touring Restomod. 1940 Ford Coupe Restomod - Art Deco Meets Modern Muscle Gateway Classic Cars of St. Louis is proud to digitally present this breathtaking 1940 Ford Coupe Restomod - a one-of-a-kind fusion of 1940s art-deco design and modern engineering excellence. With its chopped stance, widened steel body, and mirror-black finish, this car doesn't just turn heads - it stops time. Starting life with the complete frame and drivetrain of a 2005 Chevrolet SSR, the foundation was sandblasted, clear-coated, and buffed to mirror before the all-steel 1940 Ford body was grafted on. The team at Bowden Customs of Riverton, Illinois executed a jaw-dropping transformation: six inches added down the centerline for a broader, more aggressive profile, and a six-inch roof chop that gives the car its sinister silhouette. The body and paint alone represent over 1, 000 labor hours of hand-built artistry. Inside, the craftsmanship continues. The custom SSR-based interior, finished by Twin City Upholstery of Bloomington, Illinois, wraps you in deep red leather with black accents and modern comfort amenities - 10-way power heated seats, power windows and locks, cruise control, and a Kenwood premium sound system. The design bridges classic hot-rod flair with contemporary refinement. Performance comes from a 390-horsepower LS2 V8 engine paired with a 4-speed automatic transmission, delivering both muscle and smooth drivability. Air-ride suspension allows you to adjust ride height at will, combining stance and comfort seamlessly. With just 6, 093 miles since the build, this masterpiece is as fresh as it is ferocious. Modern safety enhancements include anti-lock brakes, traction control, dual airbags, and even a backup camera, making this showpiece as practical as it is stunning. Aggressive. Sculpted. Timeless. This 1940 Ford Coupe Restomod represents the golden age of design reimagined for the modern era - a rolling work of art that commands presence from every angle. This 1940 Ford Coupe Restomod can be seen at the St. Louis Showroom located at 1237 Central Park Drive, O'Fallon IL 62269. Highlights: All-steel 1940 Ford body widened 6" and chopped 6" by Bowden Customs Built on 2005 Chevrolet SSR frame and drivetrain LS2 6.0L V8 engine producing 390 HP 4-speed automatic transmission Air-ride suspension system Over 1, 000 hours in body and paint fabrication Custom red leather interior by Twin City Upholstery Power heated seats, windows, and locks Cruise control, Kenwood stereo, and backup camera Modern safety: ABS, traction control, airbags 6, 093 miles since completion A masterclass in craftsmanship blending art deco styling with modern performance First Name Please provide a first name. Gateway Classic Cars of Louisville is proud to digitally present this 1979 Pontiac Firebird Trans Am, a true classic that embodies the spirit of American muscle with a rare and stunning Atlantis Blue exterior. It is believed per owner to have 10800 miles and a original unrestored survivor. ENGINE COMPARTMENT: Under the hood lies the highly desirable 400 engine with the W72 performance package, featuring chrome valve covers. This is the original VIN-matching motor with original components, showcasing an engine compartment that remains largely original. Minor maintenance items include converting the air conditioning to 134, replacing radiator hoses, and installing a new alternator and battery. The shaker air cleaner assembly is complete with all its ductwork, and all vacuum lines are still connected. Original stickers remain on the master cylinder and brake lines. EXTERIOR: The Atlantis Blue exterior is a rare and beautiful color, believed to be the original paint that still shows remarkably well. The bumpers and spoilers fit seamlessly, and the optional hood bird remains in like-new condition. The shaker scoop is untouched, and the optional side moldings and metal door edge guards have preserved the car's pristine appearance. The 15x8 snowflake aluminum wheels are in good condition, complemented by recently replaced radial tires. The glass T-tops are in good shape and come with optional locks. The door jambs are pristine, featuring an oil change sticker from 1990, and the window seals and weather strips are in good condition. The original dealer Schaefer Pontiac emblem is still present, highlighting the car's timeless condition. INTERIOR: Stepping inside, the interior is as close to new as you will find. The dash pad is mint with no cracks, and the machine-turned metal instrument panel sparkles with clean lenses and gauges, including a working clock. The tilt formula steering wheel shows no signs of wear, and even the area around the ignition is unscratched. The center console is in good condition, free from wear, breaks, or cigarette burns. The upholstery is in good condition, and the plastic trim is pristine. The headliner is nice, and all interior lights function properly. The light-colored carpet remains in great shape, with a unique carpet square found under the seat from an assembly worker. The door panels are in good condition, with the chrome piping intact. An aftermarket AM/FM radio was installed in 1980 without cutting the dash, and the original receipt is included. Additional options include a rear defroster, delay wipers, power windows, power locks, and a power trunk. The original glove box pouch contains all the books and manuals. TRUNK COMPARTMENT: The trunk compartment looks like new, with the jack stowed under the rear deck and a collapsible spare complete with the air bottle, likely never removed from the car. It features a black felt mat with an optional insulation pad underneath. The original T-top bags and floor mats are included, and the trunk light and power release are functional. The paint under the trunk lid is pristine, and the weather strip and jamb are in good condition. UNDERSIDE: The underside of this Trans Am is exceptionally well-preserved and all original. Remnants of the original paper build sheet are still attached to the rear end cover, and the fuel tank retains its original stencil ink stamp. The rear end has a painted letter G, and the drive shaft still shows painted stripes. The original exhaust system, including the catalytic converter and mufflers with GM markings, is intact, featuring chrome splitter tips. The bottom of the motor is clean and original, and the T10 4-speed is VIN number matching to this car. The floor is 100%, rock solid virgin metal. The factory seams and spot welds are clean. Even the lower inner quarters are untouched clean original metal. It came with the WS6 performance package which included upgraded shocks, firmer springs and bushings, larger sway bars and disc brakes at all 4 wheels. Title is clean and clear and ready to be transferred into your name now. Don't miss out on the opportunity to own this incredible 1979 Pontiac Firebird with its impressive list of features and timeless design. Experience a great blend of classic style and modern convenience with this exceptional vehicle. This 1979 Trans Am is offered by our Louisville Showroom and can be seen in greater detail including 100+ HD pictures and an HD video at www.GatewayClassicCars.com . Gateway Classic Cars of St. Louis is proud to digitally present this jaw-dropping 1970 Chevrolet Chevelle SS - a no-compromise Pro Touring masterpiece that blends classic muscle car presence with cutting-edge performance. Finished in a sinister Black exterior with White SS stripes over a Black TMI interior, this Chevelle is the definition of aggressive refinement. Every inch of this build has been incredibly planned and executed, resulting in a car that's equally at home dominating the drag strip, carving corners, or cruising with modern comfort. With just 5, 192 miles since completion, this build is still fresh and ready for its next caretaker. At its heart is a Bulletproof Racing-built Supercharged 6.0L LSA V8, dyno-proven at 581 RWHP and 8 lbs of boost courtesy of a Boost District supercharger. The engine is backed by a Bowler Stage 2 T56 carbon edition 6-speed manual transmission and a McLeod Racing RXT clutch, ensuring every ounce of power is delivered to the pavement with precision. Supporting the power is a complete performance driveline including a Strange Engineering 12-bolt Posi rear with 3.55 gears and 31-spline axles. Handling and stopping are equally impressive - QA1 adjustable coilovers, UMI rear suspension, Wilwood 4-wheel disc brakes with 6-piston fronts and 4-piston rears, and Michelin Pilot Super Sport tires mounted on Weld S71 wheels (18x9 front, 18x10 rear). The exhaust note is pure American thunder thanks to a 3-inch stainless Borla Type X system. Inside, you'll find a blend of vintage style and modern tech - TMI seats, Clayton Machine Works interior hardware, Ididit steering column, Dakota Digital HDX gauges, Dynamat insulation, and a Kenwood audio system with Kenwood subs and Rockford Fosgate speakers. Vintage Air keeps the cabin cool, while Ring Brothers hood hinges, Dapper Lighting HDR headlights, and a PRC radiator with progressive fans add to the overall show-quality execution. Key Highlights: Bulletproof Racing Supercharged 6.0L LSA V8 - 581 RWHP / 8 lbs boost Bowler Stage 2 T56 Carbon Edition 6-speed manual McLeod Racing RXT clutch Black exterior w/ White SS stripes TMI custom black interior Vintage Air Wilwood 4-wheel disc brakes (6-piston front / 4-piston rear) QA1 adjustable coilovers UMI rear suspension and tubular control arms Strange 12-bolt Posi rear w/ 3.55 gears & 31-spline axles Weld S71 wheels - 18x9 front / 18x10 rear Michelin Pilot Super Sport tires 3" stainless Borla Type X exhaust Dakota Digital HDX gauges Dynamat sound insulation Kenwood audio system w/ subs and Rockford Fosgate speakers Dapper Lighting HDR headlights PRC radiator w/ progressive fans Rear-mounted Optima battery w/ disconnect Ring Brothers hood hinges Less than 5, 200 miles since completion Collector Notes: This Chevelle is the ultimate Pro Touring build - a stunning blend of classic muscle car design, modern performance hardware, and long-distance comfort. It offers show-winning presentation with track-capable engineering, making it a truly versatile and highly desirable example of the Chevelle SS legacy. See 100+ HD photos and a full HD video at gatewayclassiccars.com or Visit us in person at 1237 Central Park Drive, O'Fallon, Illinois 62269 to see this incredible Chevelle in person. transmission: 727 Torque Flight  W/ Gear Vendors Overdrive
description: Gateway Classic Cars of San Antonio/Austin is excited to present this 1964 Plymouth Fury. The sleek lines and bold presence of this Fury make it a standout on any road, capturing the attention of enthusiasts and collectors alike. Under the hood lies the heart of this beast: a 440 with a 4.350-inch bore and a stroke of 4.250 to bring the displacement to 505cid. The motor was also upgraded with a steel crank, h-beam rods, forged pistons, Edelbrock Victor heads and intake, a two-piece valley plate, Hughes hydraulic roller cam, Morrell roller lifters, Hughes 1.6 roller rockers, a Holley HP carb, MSD 6AL Ignition, MSD Pro billet distributor, and a PRC Radiator. The 727 Torqueflight transmission was rebuilt and sends power through the custom driveshaft to the 8 3/4 posi rear end with 3.73 gears. Safety and control are paramount in this classic vehicle, with features such as Calvert Racing shocks, CalTracs traction bars, custom frame rail connectors, power brakes and power steering providing enhanced handling and stopping power. The inclusion of seatbelts underscores a commitment to safety, ensuring peace of mind for both driver and passengers. For those with a passion for performance, the racing slicks offer an added edge, delivering exceptional traction and stability. The one-piece aluminum dash was cut by water jet and crafted a custom headliner with an aluminum insert to match the dash. Gateway Classic Cars Detroit is proud to present 1932 Ford Roadster. Your chance to own a piece of hot rod history! This 1932 roadster is truly one of a kind. Featured in the American Rodder magazine from March of 1964 and 'retired' shortly after, this car hasn't changed in all those years! Show winner in the 1963 show known now as Autorama. A year before the 'Riddler award'! This roadster has a 283 bored-out to a 301 Chevy engine with a Herbert roller cam, 4-71 GMC supercharger and 4 Stromberg 97 carburetors. Paired with a 39 ford 3 speed transmission. This candy apple roadster has a 3-inch chopped top, French door hinges and shaved door handles. This car is a true time capsule from the 60s hot rod scene! Gateway Classic Cars Houston Showroom is excited to offer this one of a kind 1972 Chevrolet Nova for sale. The alluring Rosewood Pearl exterior is paired beautifully with a chestnut brown interior to create a classy aesthetic. Under the hood of this sleek whip is a potent GM Performance Parts ZZ383 V8 engine, which is backed by a 6-speed manual transmission. The peppy 383 is topped with aluminum heads, and Edelbrock Pro-Flo XT port fuel injection with its corresponding high-rise aluminum intake. A set of custom stainless headers, and a 3-inch custom dual exhaust system help this mighty mouse breathe and they also provide that awesome muscle car sound! Further custom and performance touches include a Heidts custom front clip with antisway bar and tubular control arms, a custom Champion aluminum radiator with twin electric fans, a serpentine accessory drive, adjustable coilover shocks at all 4 corners, and a McLeod hydraulic clutch assist with American Powertrain Atomic twin-disc clutch. Inside, this 1972 Nova offers exceptional comfort and modern conveniences. An AutoMeter UltraLite gauge cluster provides a vintage look with modern accuracy for reporting key systems' status. The custom diamond-stitch leather seating (with power driver seat) ensures a plush and adjustable driving experience (plus, the cabin has that wonderful aroma that high-grade hides emanate). Adding to the driving pleasure is a Vintage Air HVAC system, keeping the cabin cool and comfortable on every journey. The chromed Flaming River tilt steering column with a grippy thick-rimmed steering wheel provides both style and ergonomic control, while the power steering with Flaming River rack ensures precise maneuverability. A RetroSound AM/FM/XM radio equipped with Bluetooth connectivity, allows you to enjoy your favorite tunes and stay connected on the go. The power windows offer convenience and ease, seamlessly integrating modern amenities into this classic vehicle. The addition of the custom center console, with its polished redwood insert also has cupholders for front passengers. Safety and performance have been enhanced with power disc brakes featuring 6-piston Wilwood front calipers and 4-piston rears, which grab its drilled/slotted rotors with a vengeance. The addition of low-profile performance radial tires and Foose wheels not only boosts the vehicle's aesthetic appeal but also ensures a smooth and reliable ride. Whether you're a collector or a classic car enthusiast, this 1972 Chevrolet Nova offers a unique blend of vintage charm and modern conveniences, making it a remarkable addition to any garage. Further enhancing the visual appeal are the special LED-enhanced headlights, which can really provide a show when the outer ring of LEDs is turned on. Under the hood, this classic is powered by a robust 5.7L LS1 V8 engine paired with a 4-speed automatic 4L60E transmission that sends the power out back to the 3.42:1-geared, Posi-Trac equipped 12-bolt rear end, providing a driving experience that's as thrilling as it is smooth. The potent LS1 features a WARR Performance 92MM throttle body, 92MM F.A.S.T. intake, and PRC (Performance Rod and Custom) aluminum heads. Coated headers scavenge the exhaust into the true dual system, which features stainless mufflers and electric cutouts for when you want your neighbors to know you're heading out to rumble. The massive custom aluminum radiator and custom A/C condenser are courtesy of PRC, and they look fabulous in addition to doing their job superbly. Twin electric fans further aid the cooling and sap zero horsepower. Inside, the Bel Air is transformed with custom black leather seating featuring eye-catching red inserts, offering both luxury and style. The custom center console is equipped with convenient cupholders, emphasizing functionality without sacrificing aesthetics. Drivers will appreciate the full complement of AutoMeter gauges, ensuring all essential information is clearly displayed, and the chromed tilt steering column paired with a leather-wrapped billet aluminum steering wheel adds to the refined interior experience. This Chevrolet Bel Air is not just about looks; it has been engineered for performance. It boasts a custom front suspension with tubular control arms and adjustable coilover shocks, along with a custom adjustable multilink rear suspension, also featuring coilover shocks. Performance braking is assured with a Wilwood high-pressure master cylinder, proportioning valve, and 6-piston Wilwood calipers gripping slotted and drilled rotors at all four corners, ensuring confident stops. For those who seek a superior audio experience, the AM/FM/CD radio has been enhanced by a Massive Audio Blade BP800.4 amplifier driving Massive Audio Triaxial speakers strategically placed in the parcel shelf. Hankook low-profile performance radial tires wrapped around custom American Racing Torq Thrust aluminum wheels ensure grip and aesthetic appeal. Convenience features are abundant, including power locks with remote door poppers, power steering, and power windows. The glass (except the windshield) is real smoked glass, offering both comfort and a more stylish look. The driver's seat is 6-way power adjustable, ensuring an optimal driving position. Finally, the air conditioning system ensures a pleasant cabin environment, making every journey as enjoyable as the last. This 1956 Chevrolet Bel Air is a testament to the art of classic car restoration, offering vintage beauty with contemporary enhancements, making it a great choice for enthusiasts who appreciate both heritage and modernity in their vehicles. Contact our Houston Showroom today to add it to your collection. First Name Please provide a first name. Last Name Please provide a last name. Email Please provide an email address. Gateway Classic Cars of Tampa is proud to offer this Superformance 1965 Shelby Cobra Replica. "Hey little Cobra don't you know you're gonna shut 'em down." (The Rip Chords 1963). In the early 1960s when Carroll Shelby took a British AC Ace and shoved an American V8 under the hood not only did it put Ferrari on notice, it took the Automotive world by storm. On the track and on the street, nothing could touch a Shelby Cobra. Original production Cobra's are very hard to come by and can run deep into the the six figures or even higher. Of the builders creating Cobra replica's today, Superformance is the only one licensed by Shelby automotive - www.superformance.com/factory-models/mkiii . Since 1996, Superformance has produced only a very limited number of Cobra's and maintain their reputation for quality and being most like the original production models. This '65 SC MKIII has been in the possession of it's current owner since 2001. Before bringing the car to Gateway, the RDI 351w powerplant was freshened up and now produces just shy of 500hp. That may not be in the 600-700hp range of some of today's supercars, but this Cobra tips the scales at only 2500lbs making it scary fast. You won't find frivolous man card revoking creature comforts like Nav, a back up camera, traction control, or parking assist here. You get a steering wheel, a gear shifter for your Tremec 5-speed, and a seat with side pipes spitting fire in your ear drums telling you to be a man! New Cooper Cobra tires were recently installed and an alignment performed making this beast road ready. Included with the sale are the top, side curtains, tonneau cover and a full car cover. Gateway Classic Cars of Tampa is proud to offer this gorgeous 1960 Austin Healey 3000 BT7. When the Austin-Healeys took to the twisting and winding British countryside roads in 1952, they were unlike any other automobile of the the day. After seven decades, the stylish little sports cars have developed quite a loyal following on multiple continents. This 3000 BT7 is one of the "Big Healey Roadsters" and was the recipient of a professional restoration approximately a decade ago. The current owner has provided a tote full of paperwork, documents, manuals, and awards for this show stopper. The two tone combination of black and ivory work beautifully together in creating a true work of art. Inside the cabin, you'll discover subtle black leather interior with caramel colored inserts and pipping. The detailed engine bay houses a 2.9l inline six cylinder which runs strong and smooth and when combined to the 4-speed manual transmission creates a thrilling driving experience. If you are a fan of these classic "Motors" from across the pond, you'll be hard pressed to find a better "Big Healey" than this one! It's time for a, "Spot of tea" and time on the open road. This 1960 Austin Healey BT7 is listed by our Tampa Showroom and can be viewed in greater detail including 100+ HD pictures and an HD video at www.GatewayClassicCars.com . Gateway Classic Cars Houston Showroom is proud to offer this amazing 1941 Willys Coupe for sale. This beauty is covered in a gorgeous House of Kolor Cinnamon Pearl and Silver Pearl paint scheme and boy does it get attention! Almost under the hood is a 496 CID V8, which is topped by a B&M 871 blower with dual 750 CFM Edelbrock carbs that feed the Bill "Grumpy" Jenkins-modified oval port heads. Backing that nasty Rat Motor is a Rosser Turbo 400 3-speed automatic that's more than up to the task of getting that big block's power out back to the Fab 9 rear end and its 31-spline Moser axles. A set of light weight Weld Pro Star wheels almost manage to hide the power-assisted disc brakes at each corner, but not quite. Radial tires wrap each wheel, including the massive rears, which are 15x31x18.50 Mickey Thompson meats. Underneath, the one-off custom fabricated frame was made just for this build. It features matching Cinnamon Pearl coating, adjustable chromed multilink rear suspension with coilover shocks, polished tubular front control arms and coilover shocks, and even a built-in drive shaft safety loop. Inside, occupants are treated to the beautiful light gray synthetic leather that covers virtually every surface one might touch. The use of billet aluminum door pulls and trim pieces adds sophistication as well. Drivers will enjoy the polished chrome tilt steering column, which adds a level of comfort adjustment in addition to its good looks. That column is topped by a polished billet steering wheel, which goes nicely with the other billet trim. The dash and console are fitted with white faced AutoMeter gauges for great readability. Both occupants will enjoy the power windows, along with the tunes provided by the AM/FM/CD head unit in the overhead console, and the year 'round comfort that the HVAC system provides. Safety is not overlooked, either, with seatbelts for both driver and passenger. If you're looking for that classic Willys hot rod look and the power of a giant blower-fed big block, look no further. Call or email our Houston Showroom to make it yours! First Name Please provide a first name. Last Name Please provide a last name. Email Please provide an email address. Gateway Classic Cars of Louisville is proud to present this 1969 Chevrolet Chevelle 396! The 1969 Chevelle is a legend of the muscle car era. Bold styling, wide stance, and Chevrolet's big-block 396 made it a street favorite then and a collector's favorite today. This example is finished in a deep burgundy that sets off its muscular lines. Chrome bumpers and trim add contrast, and the stance is spot-confident and aggressive. Inside, the cabin is finished in black. A bench seat stretches across, keeping the look true to the period. Factory-style gauges and the classic Hurst shifter make the driver's seat a purposeful place to be. Modern air conditioning has been neatly integrated for added comfort. Under the hood is the heart of it all: a 396 cubic-inch big block V8. It's backed by a 4-speed manual, delivering the kind of power and control enthusiasts want. Supporting upgrades include an Edelbrock intake, MSD ignition, and polished valve covers with a chrome air cleaner. Power steering and power brakes round out the package. The bay is tidy, detailed, and ready to impress. This Chevelle comes well-equipped with its 396 V8, 4-speed manual transmission, Edelbrock intake, MSD ignition, power steering, power brakes, bench seat, factory gauges, rally wheels, and integrated air conditioning. Picture the drive. The big block fires with a deep, steady rumble. You ease into first and the car pulls strong, torque pressing you into the seat. Each shift comes quick, each gear sharper than the last. The exhaust echoes, the stance holds, and the road unwinds. This Chevelle is more than steel and horsepower-it's a reminder of why the muscle car era still stirs the soul. This 1969 Chevrolet Chevelle 396 is listed by our Louisville showroom and can be viewed in greater detail including 100+ HD pictures and HD video at www.GatewayClassicCars.com . For additional information, please call our knowledgeable staff or email us at Louisville@ GatewayClassicCars.com. Our Louisville showroom is located at 13576 Blue Lick Rd. Gateway Classic cars Milwaukee is excited to present this 1968 Chevrolet Chevelle SS. This is a frame-off restoration painted in its original factory Matador Red (RR). Matched up with a restored black vinyl interior. Every measure was taken in keeping this Chevelle true to its original specifications except for the addition of an upgraded Richmond T-10 four-speed manual transmission. Under the hood of this beauty is the original 396-325HP engine. Complete with OEM or correct reproduction parts including a Rochester Quadra Jet four-barrel carburetor, cast iron intake manifold, heads, exhaust manifold, distributor, and the original snorkel air cleaner. Other features include a 12-bolt rear end, posi-traction, dual exhaust, manual steering, and manual brakes. The striking SS exterior features include Rally wheels w/ trim rings and caps mounted on Firestone Reproduction Redline Polyglas tires (F70x14), T-3 headlights, single sport mirror, and tinted glass. Gateway Classic Cars of St. Louis is proud to digitally present this 1957 Chevrolet 150 Black Widow Tribute. The Black Widow is one of the most fascinating legends in Chevrolet's racing history. In June of 1957, the Automobile Manufacturers Association banned automakers from officially participating in racing. Publicly, GM and others complied - but behind the scenes, Chevrolet kept the spirit alive. Former Hudson race engineer Vince Piggins set up operations under SEDCO (Southern Engineering and Development Co.) at Nalley Chevrolet in Atlanta, turning humble Chevy 150 sedans into NASCAR terrors. Known as "Black Widows, " these lightweight, stripped-down cars became dominant on the track, and to this day remain a point of pride and heated debate among Chevrolet enthusiasts. This tribute to that history takes the Black Widow concept into the modern era. Under the hood sits a supercharged 6.2L LSA V8 - the same powerplant found in the Camaro ZL1 and Cadillac CTS-V - delivering modern muscle far beyond anything possible in 1957. Paired with a Tremec 6-speed manual transmission, this '57 combines raw horsepower with an engaging, driver-focused experience. Supporting the power are modern conveniences that make this car as usable as it is thrilling: Power steering for smooth maneuverability Power brakes for confident stopping AM/FM radio for cruising comfort Finished in the distinctive Black Widow tribute livery, this Chevrolet 150 captures the look of a NASCAR legend while bringing modern engineering to the mix. It's both a respectful nod to history and a bold reimagining of what the Black Widow could be today. Gateway Classic Cars of Philadelphia is proud to digitally present this striking 1966 Chevrolet Chevelle SS finished in vibrant Corvette Yellow. This true 138-coded SS has been lovingly owned by the same caretaker since 1985, undergoing a full body-off-frame restoration where no expense was spared. The result is a car that not only turns heads but also delivers the kind of performance muscle car enthusiasts dream about. Under the hood, you'll find a freshly rebuilt 396ci V8-sourced from a '69 Camaro-built to a high-performance spec and rated at 375 horsepower (Code JH, .060 over). This engine features a Lunati Solid Cam (#40208) with impressive lift and duration, ceramic-coated Hooker headers, and Flowmaster exhaust, delivering a throaty, unmistakable muscle car sound. For reliability and drivability, it's equipped with an MSD 6A ignition system, MSD HEI distributor, blaster coil, and a Demon 750 dual-feed carburetor mounted on an Edelbrock RPM intake. Power is delivered through a crisp-shifting Muncie M21 4-speed manual transmission paired with a Hurst Competition Plus shifter, ensuring an authentic and engaging driving experience. At the rear, a stout 12-bolt differential with 3.70 Richmond gears, Moser axles, and heat-treated spider gears puts the power to the pavement. Inside, the Chevelle has been fully restored with black bucket seat interior, retaining its classic muscle car style while offering a fresh, factory-correct feel. Every detail was carefully chosen during the restoration, and extensive documentation-including receipts and photographs-is available to verify the build and craftsmanship that went into this machine. Owned and loved, by the same individual for nearly four decades, this Chevelle SS is more than just a car-it's a passion project brought to life with true attention to detail and care. Whether you're looking to enjoy weekend cruises, add a serious collector piece to your garage, or simply own one of the most iconic muscle cars of the 1960s, this 1966 Chevrolet Chevelle SS is ready to deliver. Key Features & Highlights: True 138 SS Car Corvette Yellow exterior / Black bucket seat interior Rebuilt 396ci V8 ('69 Camaro block) - 375hp JH Code, .060 Over Lunati Solid Cam #40208 - .558 Intake Lift / 310 Duration, .556 Exhaust Lift / 320 Duration Ceramic-coated Hooker headers with Flowmaster exhaust MSD 6A ignition, MSD HEI distributor, Blaster coil Holley EFI with Demon 750 dual-feed carburetor / Edelbrock RPM intake Muncie M21 4-speed manual w/ Hurst Competition Plus shifter 12-bolt rear differential - 3.70 Richmond gears, Moser axles, heat-treated spider gears Full body-off-frame restoration Same owner since 1985 - extensive receipts & photos available The 1966 Chevelle is listed by our Philadelphia Showroom and can be viewed in greater detail including 100+ HD pictures and an HD video at www.GatewayClassicCars.com . Gateway classic cars of Nashville is pleased to digitally present to you this 1967 Chevrolet Malibu. Wow! Just Wow! This car takes days to see all the improvements that have been skillfully completed. Every nut, Bolt, line and wire has been thought through and installed properly. Not sure where to start so, it is white with red interior. The white paint on this '67 Malibu looks killer, smooth and glossy. I can only imagine the time and effort put into this car. The frame a power coated and made into a roller with ride tech air ride on all four corners as well as 4-wheel disc brakes. Strong arm was the choice for the trailing arms and A arms as well as sway bars. Then the 383 cubic inch stroker was attached to the turbo 400 3 speed automatic transmission and installed in the frame along with the 12-bolt rear axle housing 3.41:1 gear set. The 383 stroker has Brodix heads, Edelbrock air gap intake and pro form 4-barrel, double pumper carb, this gives this big girl the juice to light up the rear tires if you get mad at them. MSD Pro billet distributor with blaster 2 coil, light the fires and Hedman headers help it exhale easier. Anywhere you look this car will impress you. No corners cut, no short cuts taken and I am sure one bank account dented, hard! Options for this 1967 Malibu include: A/C, AM/FM, Power steering and brakes, Air ride suspension, Seat belts, positraction, and radial tires. Gateway Classic Cars of Dallas is proud to present this exceptionally rare 1969 Ford Mustang Mach 1 T5, finished in Candy Apple Red over a black cloth interior. More than just a classic pony car, this is a documented example of a unique German-delivery T5 model, one of the most fascinating variations in Ford Mustang history. This vehicle was built at the Metuchen, New Jersey plant and exported to West Germany as part of Ford's overseas delivery program during a time when the Mustang name could not be used due to copyright conflicts. In the 1960s, a West German manufacturer held the trademark rights to the name "Mustang, " which meant Ford was unable to use the nameplate for vehicles sold in that country. Rather than purchase the rights, Ford chose to identify the export models using the internal design code: T5. As a result, cars like this one received modified badging and omitted all references to the Mustang name while retaining the same mechanical specifications, trim levels, and performance capabilities. These cars were sold through West German Ford dealerships or to American servicemen stationed in Europe via military PX programs. This particular T5 was originally purchased on May 7, 1969, by U.S. Army Captain Thomas Reichert from the American PX outside of Wurzburg, Germany. Captain Reichert chose the T5 Mach 1 over a Cyclone GT based on its design and took delivery of the vehicle at the Port of Bremerhaven. He later had the car professionally rustproofed in Rotterdam, Netherlands. The car reportedly attracted significant attention, with local police often stopping his wife just to admire the vehicle. After approximately 6, 000 miles of use overseas, the car was brought back to the United States in early 1970. Since then, it has had only two other owners: Michael Pettitt from 1985 to 1995, and John Pelletier from 1995 to 2021. This T5 is powered by a completely rebuilt with receipts 351 cubic inch V8 engine mated to a Ford FMX 3-speed automatic transmission and comes equipped with air conditioning, power brakes, power steering, aluminum wheels, AM/FM radio, seatbelts, radial tires, and a mix of cloth and vinyl upholstery. As a T5, it features the required unique badging and branding that replaced all Mustang references, making it a one-of-a-kind vehicle with direct ties to Cold War-era export policy and military history. T5 Mustangs were only produced in small numbers, and Ford did not maintain precise production records. Estimates suggest that fewer than 300 of these export models have been located and verified today. This particular car's traceable ownership and early documentation make it especially noteworthy. For collectors seeking a distinctive variation of the 1969 Mach 1, this German-delivery Ford T5 offers a compelling combination of rarity, provenance, and historical importance. 1 of 1 Elite Marti Report Included. Over $25k in recent maintenance receipts are included with the sale of the car from 2023 to now. This 1969 Ford Mustang Mach 1 is listed by our Dallas Showroom and can be viewed in greater detail including 100+ HD pictures and an HD video at www.GatewayClassicCars.com . For additional information, please call our knowledgeable staff at (817)-310-9400 or email us at Dallas@ GatewayClassicCars.com. Our Dallas Showroom is located at 1250 Mustang Drive Suite 500, Grapevine, TX 76051. Hours: Monday through Saturday, 9 AM to 5 PM CST, please reach out to set an appointment. Gateway Classic Cars Fort Lauderdale is proud to present this 1969 Chevrolet Chevelle Pro-Street Car! Take a look at this baby. The custom paint was sprayed by JJJ Enterprises in Fort Lauderdale. House of Colors Candy Brandy Wine with Candy Burple & Candy Violet graphics were applied. It's pretty obvious this thing means business with the massive rear tires, lowered stance, and SOUND. The 8 cylinder symphony is courtesy of a 498 Big Block Chevrolet, all 818 horsepower and 740 ft. lbs. of torque worth. It features a Cola forged crank, JE 14.5-1 pistons, and Eagle forged steel rods. Valve action comes by way of a Competition Cams roller version, along with roller rockers, double springs and titanium retainers on Manley values. A Kinsler fuel injection system feeds the hungry 8 cylinders with methanol. Custom tubes and air cleaner by the owner. The frame is a full round tubular double funny car cage designed and built by the owner. Tubular a-arms, coil over shocks, 4-link setup, Wilwood disk brakes, and a 9" Ford with 4:88's gets all that power to the pavement. A 37-gallon stainless tank readies the fuel for delivery. And check this out- it has a a built in 3-point jack system! Heck, there is even a 3rd brake light just for fun. The interior is really nice, courtesy of Creative Trim in Pompano Beach FL. Te all gray leather with suede accents it much nicer than your typical pro-street interior, and the custom dash wih auto-meter gauges looks killer. There is just too much to list. Gateway Classic Cars of Dallas presents your chance to step back in time and experience the thrill of the 1965 Superformance Cobra MKIII Roadster, a masterful tribute to one of the most iconic cars in automotive history. This particular model boasts a striking blue and white exterior that captures the essence of its racing pedigree, while the black leather interior adds a touch of luxury to its raw performance appeal. Under the hood, the Cobra is powered by a formidable 351W-418 CID Stroker V8 engine, paired with a Tremec 5 Speed manual transmission, Wide 17" Wheels with Nitto Tires and Fully Indepentant suspension Front and Rear promise an exhilarating driving experience that echoes the spirit of the original AC Cobra, Wrapped into a Modern Superformance Chassis that demands your interest. The history of the AC Cobra is nothing short of legendary. Born from the brilliant collaboration between American automotive designer Carroll Shelby and British automaker AC Cars, the Cobra first roared to life in the early 1960s. Shelby's vision was to create a sports car that combined the lightweight, nimble chassis of the British AC Ace with the potent power of a Ford V8 engine. The result was a car that dominated racetracks and captured the imaginations of car enthusiasts worldwide. The Cobra's racing successes and stunning performance cemented its place in automotive lore, making it a timeless symbol of speed and power. Inside this Superformance Cobra MKIII Roadster, you'll find features that blend classic style with modern sensibility. The black leather interior is complemented by aluminum wheels that enhance both the car's aesthetics and its driving dynamics. Power brakes ensure confident stopping power, while seatbelts provide added safety, allowing you to enjoy the thrill of the drive with peace of mind. This vehicle is a testament to the enduring appeal of the Cobra, offering a driving experience that is as visceral and exciting today as it was in its heyday. Whether you are a collector seeking a piece of automotive history or an enthusiast looking to experience the raw power and craftsmanship of a bygone era, the 1965 Superformance Cobra MKIII Roadster is an exceptional choice. It stands as a tribute to the original AC Cobra, capturing the essence of what made the Cobra a legend on the track and an icon on the road. This 1965 Superformance Cobra MKIII Roadster is listed by our Dallas Showroom and can be viewed in greater detail including 100+ HD pictures and an HD video at www.GatewayClassicCars.com . For additional information, please call our knowledgeable staff at (817)-310-9400 or email us at Dallas@ GatewayClassicCars.com. Gateway Classic Cars Houston showroom is proud to present this classic 1965 Chevrolet Corvette. This striking red exterior 1965 Chevrolet Corvette turns heads while carrying forward a storied American legacy. Chevrolet's firstgeneration Corvettes, the C1s, were produced from 1953 through 1962 and established the Corvette as a symbol of postwar innovation, sporty design, and fiberglass bodywork that set the pace for future generations. Though the 1965 model is technically a C2, it stands upon the traditions that the C1s created-bold styling, open-air driving, and engine performance that connected enthusiast dreams with the open road. Step up to this red Corvette and take in the contrast of the vibrant paint against the black vinyl interior. The cabin is simple and purposeful, with seatbelts for safety, a manual convertible top that lets you control whether you breathe in open skies or enjoy shel-tered cruising. The interior upholstery in vinyl adds durability and classic style, keeping things clean, strong, and fitting for a build that refuses to over-embellish. Power comes from a 327 cubic inch V8, an engine known for solid performance in its era, paired with an automatic transmission that gives smooth, relaxed shifts and makes highway travel effortless. You can feel the torque roll out in low RPMs, making this Corvette work happily in traffic or enjoying a steady cruise. This car embraces original simplicity rather than modern luxuries. The radio setup is basic: AM only, supplemented by a cassette tape player, offering a retro way to enjoy your favorite tapes or broadcasts. Other period-correct features include hub caps that carry the style and charm of 1960s design, manually operated top, and classic control layout. Each component reinforces the classic character and driving purity this Corvette offers. For those seeking a vintage convertible that embodies authentic mid-sixties Chevrolet performance with a lean, no-frills interior, this red-on-black 327 V8 automatic Corvette delivers. It is a car to drive, to show, and to enjoy for its timeless appeal. First Name Please provide a first name. Last Name Please provide a last name. Email Please provide an email address. Gateway Classic Cars of Louisville is proud to present this stunning 1968 Chevrolet Chevelle SS 396 4-Speed! Few cars define the golden age of muscle like the Chevelle Super Sport. With its wide stance, flowing lines, and thunderous big-block power, the 1968 SS captures the spirit of late-'60s performance. Finished in deep black, this Chevelle looks every bit the part-bold, confident, and ready to run. Powering this legend is a 396 cubic-inch big block V8 mated to a 4-speed manual transmission, backed by a 3.76 rear gear ratio. The result is pure, old-school excitement-torque you can feel, sound you can't forget, and the unmistakable satisfaction of rowing through the gears. Importantly, this isn't just another Chevelle wearing SS badges. It left the factory as a true Super Sport, verified by its 138 VIN designation, Chevrolet's code for authentic SS models in 1968. Upgraded Wilwood drilled and slotted disc brakes with 4-piston front and 6-piston rear calipers provide confident stopping power, while Vintage Air conditioning adds modern comfort. The refreshed black vinyl interior stays true to its heritage and surrounds the driver in simple, purposeful style. Behind the wheel, this Chevelle delivers everything a true muscle car should-the sound, the feel, the rush. It's not just transportation; it's an experience that connects you to a time when power ruled the streets. This 1968 Chevrolet Chevelle SS 396 4-Speed is offered by our Louisville Showroom and can be viewed in greater detail including 100+ HD pictures and an HD video at www.GatewayClassicCars.com . Gateway Classic Cars of Fort Lauderdale is proud to present this very special 1971 Chevrolet Chevelle convertible in green on green. Originally a special order vehicle from Vandergriff Chevrolet in Arlington, TX, this '71 Chevelle is unlike most. Equipped with an extremely rare factory option of the Chevy 400ci big block motor. Because the Malibu sport coupe and convertible received the "Malibu" emblem, rare combinations such as this are often referred to as a "Malibu 400". Despite Chevrolet ever officially designating this term. These badges can be found on both front quarter panels. A Vandergriff badge sits on the trunk lid. The owner of this Malibu has provided documentation including the build sheet, and the vehicles protect-o-plate. This '71 is one of the few and finest examples of Malibu's still out there. The metallic green exterior is purely stunning; an absolute head tuner. A very unique shade of lime green. Resemblant of not just a lime, but also a sour apple, or even a jolly rancher. Matched with a beautiful set of rally style wheels, and a dark green Interior. Inside and out this Chevelle is in gorgeous shape. A hidden gem. First Name Please provide a first name. Gateway Classic Cars of Tampa introduces this classic 1965 Chevrolet Corvette Convertible. The C2 Stingray is a perineal classic of automotive design. Packing an array of powerful V8s, independent suspension and eye arresting styling; a 1965 Corvette convertible with air conditioning is an American icon. Under the hood is a healthy Non-Numbers Matching 396 big block, backed by a 4-speed manual, the car will definitely raise your pulse! Gateway Classic Cars is proud to present this 1966 Pontiac GTO. Introduced in 1964, the Pontiac GTO is often credited as the car that launched the muscle car era, offering affordable performance in a stylish midsize package. By 1966, the GTO had established itself as a legend, with its aggressive styling, powerful V8 engines, and a reputation for dominating both the street and the strip. That year also marked the first time the GTO became a separate model line rather than just an option package, solidifying its place in automotive history as one of the most iconic performance cars of its time. This 1966 Pontiac GTO convertible is a striking example finished in a yellow exterior paired with a black interior. Under the hood sits the legendary 389 cubic inch V8 engine, with the ever so famous 3x2 carburetor setup. A powerplant that delivered the kind of raw performance that made the GTO a household name. Mated to a manual transmission, it provides an engaging and authentic driving experience that every muscle car enthusiast craves. The car comes equipped with desirable features that blend classic style with functionality. Aluminum wheels wrapped in radial tires provide both performance and a sharp appearance, while power steering and power brakes ensure confident handling on the road. The manual convertible top allows for open-air cruising, and the am/fm radio adds period-correct entertainment to the ride. Inside, the black vinyl interior is accented with seatbelts, giving a nod to both safety and originality. For enthusiasts seeking a genuine piece of muscle car history, this 1966 Pontiac GTO offers the balance of style, performance, and heritage. Whether enjoyed on weekend drives with the top down or proudly displayed at car shows, it represents the very spirit of Pontiac's legendary performance era. First Name Please provide a first name.
